what: Tidy manipulation of fourier transformed data
title: Tidy manipulation of fourier transformed data
text: goal tidyfft make working fft’s R easier consistent. follows tidy philosophy storing output tibble.

title: Tidy manipulation of fourier transformed data
text: can install development version tidyfft GitHub :

title: Tidy manipulation of fourier transformed data
text: Using tidy_fft ggplot.
code: library(tidyfft) (     tidy_fft(sunspot.month) |>     change_repr("rect", .keep = "all") |>     change_repr("polr", .keep = "all") -> sunspot.month.fft ) #> # A tibble: 3,177 × 6 #>      dim_1 fx                          re      im     mod    arg #>      <dbl> <cpl>                    <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1 0       165092.2000+    0.000i 165092.      0  165092.  0     #>  2 0.00378  13876.3375+15850.464i  13876.  15850.  21066.  0.852 #>  3 0.00755  -2733.7209+16131.802i  -2734.  16132.  16362.  1.74  #>  4 0.0113   -8428.2640-18110.753i  -8428. -18111.  19976. -2.01  #>  5 0.0151  -14755.1410- 1860.878i -14755.  -1861.  14872. -3.02  #>  6 0.0189   -7986.8153+12940.843i  -7987.  12941.  15207.  2.12  #>  7 0.0227   -2173.4245+ 7168.128i  -2173.   7168.   7490.  1.87  #>  8 0.0264   -3395.5271- 7055.326i  -3396.  -7055.   7830. -2.02  #>  9 0.0302     572.7342- 4329.374i    573.  -4329.   4367. -1.44  #> 10 0.0340    7811.7219- 3510.364i   7812.  -3510.   8564. -0.422 #> # ℹ 3,167 more rows library(ggfortify) library(patchwork)  ggplot(fortify(sunspot.month)) +    aes(x = Index, y = Data) +    geom_line() +   xlab("Year") +   ylab("Sunspot count") +   theme_bw() -> p1  xlocs <- c(1, 0.1, 0.01) xlabs <- c("1", "10", "100")  sunspot.month.fft |>   dplyr::filter(dim_1 > 0) |>   ggplot() +     aes(x = dim_1, y = mod) +     geom_point() +     scale_y_continuous(trans = "log", labels = function(y) round(y)) +     scale_x_continuous(trans = "log", breaks = xlocs, labels = xlabs) +     xlab("Cycle duration (years)") +     ylab("Cycle amplitude") +     geom_smooth() +     theme_bw() -> p2  print(p1 / p2)

what: Check if a tidy_fft object has a specific representation — can_repr
title: Check if a tidy_fft object has a specific representation — can_repr
text: function checks given tidy_fft object contains specified representation: polar ("polr"), rectangular ("rect"), complex ("cplx").

title: Check if a tidy_fft object has a specific representation — can_repr
Check if a tidy_fft object has a specific representation — can_repr
text: x tidy_fft object. repr target representation check ("polr", "rect", "cplx").

title: Check if a tidy_fft object has a specific representation — can_repr
text: logical value (TRUE object specified representation, otherwise FALSE).

title: Check if a tidy_fft object has a specific representation — can_repr
code: tft <- tidy_fft(c(1, 0, -1, 0)) can_repr(tft, "cplx")  # Returns TRUE #> [1] TRUE can_repr(tft, "rect")  # Returns FALSE #> [1] FALSE

what: Change the representation of FFT results — change_repr
title: Change the representation of FFT results — change_repr
text: Converts FFT results different representations.

title: Change the representation of FFT results — change_repr
Change the representation of FFT results — change_repr
text: x tidy_fft object. repr target representation ("polr", "rect", "cplx"). .keep Determines columns retain output. Passed directly dplyr::mutate. Options include: "": Keep columns (default). "used": Keep columns used computation, plus new ones. "unused": Keep columns used computation, plus new ones. "none": Keep new columns.

title: Change the representation of FFT results — change_repr
text: modified object new representation.

title: Change the representation of FFT results — change_repr
code: fft_res <- tidy_fft(c(1, 0, -1, 0)) change_repr(fft_res, "rect", .keep = "none") #> # A tibble: 4 × 2 #>      re    im #>   <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     0     0 #> 2     2     0 #> 3     0     0 #> 4     2     0

what: Convert an Object to a Tidy FFT Object — .as_tidy_fft_obj
title: Convert an Object to a Tidy FFT Object — .as_tidy_fft_obj
text: internal helper function applies necessary structure class attributes convert given object tidy_fft object.

title: Convert an Object to a Tidy FFT Object — .as_tidy_fft_obj
Convert an Object to a Tidy FFT Object — .as_tidy_fft_obj
text: x input object convert, typically tibble data frame. ... Additional attributes include structured object, metadata specific attributes required Fourier Transform analysis.

title: Convert an Object to a Tidy FFT Object — .as_tidy_fft_obj
text: input object x, tidy_fft class additional attributes provided ....

title: Convert an Object to a Tidy FFT Object — .as_tidy_fft_obj
text: tidy_fft object tibble-like structure additional class attributes used represent Fourier Transform results tidy format.

what: Compute Fourier frequencies for default inputs — .fourier_frequencies
title: Compute Fourier frequencies for default inputs — .fourier_frequencies
text: Computes normalized Fourier frequencies scalar vector inputs, evenly spaced -0.5 0.5.

title: Compute Fourier frequencies for default inputs — .fourier_frequencies
Compute Fourier frequencies for default inputs — .fourier_frequencies
text: x scalar vector representing length sequence.

title: Compute Fourier frequencies for default inputs — .fourier_frequencies
text: numeric vector containing normalized Fourier frequencies.

what: Compute the number of samples in an input — .num_samples
title: Compute the number of samples in an input — .num_samples
text: helper function determines number samples input object. vector, returns length. matrix data frame, returns number rows.

title: Compute the number of samples in an input — .num_samples
Compute the number of samples in an input — .num_samples
text: x input object (scalar, vector, matrix, data frame).

title: Compute the number of samples in an input — .num_samples
text: integer representing number samples (rows) input object.

what: Compute Fourier frequencies for multidimensional arrays — fourier_frequencies.array
title: Compute Fourier frequencies for multidimensional arrays — fourier_frequencies.array
text: Computes Fourier frequencies dimension array returns tidy tibble frequencies dimensions.

title: Compute Fourier frequencies for multidimensional arrays — fourier_frequencies.array
Compute Fourier frequencies for multidimensional arrays — fourier_frequencies.array
text: x numeric array.

title: Compute Fourier frequencies for multidimensional arrays — fourier_frequencies.array
text: tibble column corresponds Fourier frequencies dimension input array. column names dim_1, dim_2, ..., corresponding dimension.

title: Compute Fourier frequencies for multidimensional arrays — fourier_frequencies.array
code: # Compute Fourier frequencies for a 3D array array_input <- array(1:27, dim = c(3, 3, 3)) fourier_frequencies(array_input) #> # A tibble: 27 × 3 #>    dim_3  dim_2  dim_1 #>    <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1 0      0      0     #>  2 0      0      0.333 #>  3 0      0     -0.333 #>  4 0      0.333  0     #>  5 0      0.333  0.333 #>  6 0      0.333 -0.333 #>  7 0     -0.333  0     #>  8 0     -0.333  0.333 #>  9 0     -0.333 -0.333 #> 10 0.333  0      0     #> # ℹ 17 more rows  # Compute Fourier frequencies for a 2D matrix matrix_input <- matrix(1:9, nrow = 3, ncol = 3) fourier_frequencies(matrix_input) #> # A tibble: 9 × 2 #>    dim_2  dim_1 #>    <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1  0      0     #> 2  0      0.333 #> 3  0     -0.333 #> 4  0.333  0     #> 5  0.333  0.333 #> 6  0.333 -0.333 #> 7 -0.333  0     #> 8 -0.333  0.333 #> 9 -0.333 -0.333  # Compute Fourier frequencies for a vector (1D case) vector_input <- 1:8 fourier_frequencies(vector_input) #> # A tibble: 8 × 1 #>    dim_1 #>    <dbl> #> 1  0     #> 2  0.125 #> 3  0.25  #> 4  0.375 #> 5  0.5   #> 6 -0.375 #> 7 -0.25  #> 8 -0.125

what: tidyfft: Tidy manipulation of fourier transformed data — tidyfft-package
title: tidyfft: Tidy manipulation of fourier transformed data — tidyfft-package
text: Provides functions storing fourier coefficients tibble manipulating various ways. main different tidy_fft base R tidy_fft computes normalized fourier frequencies cycles per stride, .e., cycles per interval samples, often point confusion new users convenient plotting, etc. frequencies coefficients stored tibble (data.frame), easy processing , e.g., dplyr facilitated.

title: tidyfft: Tidy manipulation of fourier transformed data — tidyfft-package
text: Maintainer: Timothy Keitt tkeitt@gmail.com
